D7Qbj6A0Vh0Kes1-I8qUPA.text: It was always one of the best turkish restaurants. Now getting more busy because of the Time Out. But still is a place to go. Friendly staff good food. But better go when is not busy or a long queue will wait for you in the main door

lkZ80oUsFE3yF7kgctoXmw.text: Didn't book at my friends' favourite restaurant on green lanes, and on an average night it was over 30 mins wait. While we waited though it was mouthwatering watching the delicious dishes, salads and special meat platters being prepared right in front of our eyes. We were seated round the back with some lovely traditional Turkish style decor, but it would have been preferable to have a table in the front. Food was delicious and ready quickly, and you have to try the lamb chops - wow! I'll be going back soon!

l1gGdYY0GHgHxcF9d42dLQ.text: Certainly the best Turkish restaurant outside of Turkey. The place is always packed. Very helpful staff. Just go easy on the starters otherwise you'll be too full for the main course.

5CPgsKb3rTgFJgPX_L1YkQ.text: The best Turkish restaurant in Haringay. The food is really great and there are lots of options. In addition there is quite a lot of complementary free food with every meal.

tHBiiqsOHdgRlFGHZbtG4g.text: I tried their chicken shish but the meat was so cold that it was tasteless

QbxkBm0k9x7058Hwbc1FzQ.text: This is the best Turkish restaurant I've been to anywhere.  It is flawless - the service, the food and even the interior are all superb.  But really, you come here for the food.  When you sit down, the waiters bring a generous portion of hot, fluffy Turkish bread with a terrific yoghurt sauce.  I ordered a Soğanlı Lahmacun - a very thin pide with light toppings, just amazing.  I then had the lamb chops - tender and juicy, but not fatty, seasoned perfectly.  I want to go with more people next time so I can try more of the dishes.  I spent some time checking out the meats at the counter -- and the doners looked terrific, real meats as opposed to that artificial stuff you see at many kebab houses.  Finally, the neighborhood has tons of Turkish restaurants, many were packed, so I can't wait to go back and try some more!

G6Uh2-BEVEM17daEYMIdQg.text: Came here on a Sunday night. Mixed service, not always great. Tasty food.

zMkYwob3c-mOpNwyXjSOqA.text: We travel from Norfolk 100 miles + to enjoy the the special with ayran for me yoghurt drink and it's the best value food in the UK for 2. We dine 5 star in the UK park lane, 7 star Dubai, but this restaurant is really respectful, friendly and all the staff are the best around like one big family who treat returning clients like a cousin. I really didn't want to share this wonderful secret as I want it for us. But the owners and staff deserve praise. Mashallah.Pat and Paul

u3HOTBYKdoZT82PVgaJBkQ.text: Went to this bustling and excellent Turkish restaurant and takeaway on Harringay's Grand Parade with a group of 7 last Friday. It was absolutely full, which is generally a good sign, but within three minutes we had been found a table. As with most of the Turkish places in Harringay, the resto has a big charcoal trough at the front, over which shish kebabs are cooked, and two vertical spits with chicken and lamb doner. Lest anyone be thinking of the grey elephant leg which passes for doner in most chipshops nationwide, nothing could be further from the truth. Proper doner is made from marinated offcuts of lamb layered with fatty lamb tail. This melts as the spit rotates and runs through the meat, basting it into delicious tenderness. We had mixed meze to start with. Tons of piping-hot pillow-bread to dunk into potato salad, taramasalata, spinach with yoghurt, hummus and tomato and runnerbean dips. Most of us chose to follow up with one of the various shish options - from darkly spiced kofte (minced kebab) to tender marinaded lamb cubes - all cooked over charcoal. I had mixed doner, chicken and lamb mounded on top of stock-cooked rice, and a couple of us went for the Yoghurtlu kebabs - shish piled on chopped bread, soaked in sauce and topped with warm Turkish yoghurt. More bread kept on coming, along with a couple of brightly coloured plates of salad, and we washed the whole thing down with some bottles of Efes beer. The restaurant, obviously delighted to have a table of 7 in, laid on some complementary rice pudding for dessert. Although this sounds a bit like school dinners, it was sweet, vanilla-y and actually quite pleasant. We were stuffed by the time the bill arrived, and very happy to split the £100 (including tip) that our three course meal for 7 with drinks cost. Let me just repeat that. 3 course meal for 7 with drinks. £100. Amazing. Gökyüzü, for anyone who is interested, means heaven in Turkish. Which, if they continue to serve food like this, is about right.

tKFN2gszf7lkxzQwizM0Fg.text: Love, love, LOVE the food here. There are always queues outside and I'm certainly not surprised! For the prices they have on the menu you would expect something quite mediocre but have tried a lot of the food and everything went above and beyond what you'd expect for the price. The staff are kept busy but at no point did I feel neglected or like they just wanted me to eat and leave to open up the table for new customers like so many other places. Highly recommended.

3B0VXQjhIJRw15nZO5Mm7Q.text: Standards slipping fast........... Ate there last month and was impressed with both the food and service. Unfortunately, it appears that the management put on a bit of a show following the refurbishment and have now slipped back to slapdash practices. On a recent visit, the service was poor and slow; several requests for drinks were either ignored or fulfilled halfway through the meal. The 'special mix grill' ' (£19) we ordered was supposed to contain such delicacies as lamb cutlets and quail. What arrived was a large plate consisting mainly of chicken wings and diced doner-kebab on a bed of rice! When this was pointed out to the waiter, he simply shrugged his shoulders! Furthermore, you get stung £3 for a small bottle of beer, and you can forget about the complimentary desserts and coffee they used to give - it's all gone by the wayside! It's all beginning to feel rather cynical.... Yes, it's sort of cheap, but I am afraid what you get is pretty poor.Better to try 'Hala Restaurant' a few doors away. At least you get a very decent meal and none of the aggravation.

W7KIgpQESNS-CvB94VQdaw.text: Good food and reasonably priced. However service could be improved. Firstly for bringing starter and main course together. Secondly, bringing a broken tea glass, and thirdy being slow to wait the table in busy periods.

5Bd2OZY5yYdR4EK7iunLzw.text: Been to a number of restaurants on Green Lane and have to say this is probably the best one I've been to so far. Great food, ordered the Mixed Kebab which was massive (also get rice, salad and bread), only managed to finish half of it. At the end when the waiter came over he just looked at my plate and asked if I'd like a doggy bag and offered free tea. Great friendly service! Definitely be coming back.

CHzETDTayrLE0I2mfC0Q2Q.text: Iv been to Gokyuzu Restaurant and the food was unbeleivbale. The food is the best in Green Lanes and i have never seen better then Gokyuzu Restaurant. The staff is really friendly and nd service a great. I have never seen Gokyuzu Restaurant emty and always packed. I think the best place to take friend and family out for brekfast, lunch and diner will be Gokyuzu. It is also good value for food and service they have. They offer you Turkish tea after your diner and i feel great.

NdmKKNQfqfafQrEYkt23Gg.text: Went here for the second time on Saturday night, and once again was blown away by the food, the service, and the atmosphere. We went just after it was refurbished several months ago, with a group of about 8. That time, half of the party turned up 20 minutes after the rest, and the staff didn't bat an eyelid as they sorted out extra seating and places for us all, taking our orders without rushing us but happily offering recommendations all of which were served up fairly quickly, clearly made fresh and with great flavours. This time was even better - a group of 3, we turned up to find the queue out the door but the staff very friendly and efficient as they took our names, and found us a table in under 10 minutes (after warning us it might take up to 15). Friendly family atmosphere, a lot of tables groaning under massive mixed platters (I'm definitely ordering one of those next time!) Unlimited pita bread and salad to share (very simple but very well done, with a great dressing) made us pretty happy. I had the lamb ribs - juicy with just the right amount of fat sizzling around the edges, served with fabulous rice. My friend had the lamb shish which she enjoyed very much, and even a vegetarian friend was accommodated with the mixed mezze platter. Wait staff were quick on the mark when we were looking for them, but didn't hover, and everyone around us seemed to be really enjoying themselves. All in all, one of the best eating experiences I've had locally, we're planning to make it a regular fixture.

Ydmgx4XEqJ5ltCN9WK4Dlw.text: When I read about how Gokyuzu is the best Turkish restaurant in town, my first reaction was that it's just excited Brits overrating decent Middle Eastern food.Um, no.It's really good. Always expect queues, no matter what time it is, although we never waited for more than 5 minutes. The meat platters are massive, so think again before ordering that jumbo size. The smaller one is supposedly for 1-2 person(s) but it can easily feed up to four (especially if you order starters). IMHO their lahmacun is slightly average (definitely not bad, just nothing special), but the chicken beyti is indeed exceptional. I wouldn't go anywhere else for Turkish food in London.

1VbpbYSpKW11EPCy8bLlJw.text: I visited London with my husband for our honeymoon. We don't have many Turkish restaurants in South Carolina, so this was my first experience. It was AMAZING. I still crave it to this day, and we were there over 2 years ago. The starter salad was incredibly fresh and bursting with flavor. I had the Sama Kuzu Beyti as my main course - delicious. And the tea brought out after the meal was the perfect finish. If we ever end up in London again, this is sure to be on our list of "To Do's".

fYCarF8bWlzK8DzBtwQEqg.text: This restaurant is always packed - a great sign.The food is amazing quality for the price you pay.Flat breads arrive on your table as standard, so we ordered hummus to accompany it.We then chose to have a mixed grill type dish. The menu suggested it was for between 2 - 4 people, costing £25. The food that arrived in front of us was a huge pile of meaty goodness. Lamb koftas, shish, chicken wings, chicken shish, more bread, rice, bulgar wheat, salad, and dips.It was definitely too much for two, so we requested a doggie bag and had enough for lunch the next day.Commentary baklava and hot tea rounds off the meal nicely.I wouldn't eat Turkish anywhere else in London!

l6L6HnjjiBTdkPuG2lafxA.text: The first time I visited, I was slightly disappointed as they had run out of lamb so was forced to order something I didn't want. Plus, no one came to take our order for a long time. Nevertheless, I visited again and was very pleased with the food. The portions are just right, they don't overdo it plus the salad is the best I've ever had, especially the red cabbage! They give complimentary warm bread and dips but make sure not to fill up on it as the mains are worth saving space for. The prices are very reasonable but it is a very popular restaurant and gets busy so make sure you arrive early and be prepared to wait.

cBkHUdejB1GI9WfIDNG_ng.text: When I lived round this area I used to be in here at least once a week for dinner or to grab a takeaway. This place still doesn't disappoint and packs amazing flavour in all their dishes. You get a salad and bread free as standard when you order any kebabs. The portion sizes are ridiculously huge and if you're in a group you can even get large platters that are 3-4 but does actually feed 5-6. The best bit has to be that they dab the bread over the meat to soak up more of the deliciously meaty goodness, maybe avoid if you're a veggie. The only downside is that as its popularity has grown, so has its prices (slightly) and their bottles of homemade garlic and chilli sauces seem to be more commercial and I see this expanding into a nandos type chain. I hope this doesn't happen and it keeps it uniqueness through its growth. (Visit - 12/03/2015 Lunch)

VXS5QFD_xwYzG9Wxv4DCmw.text: I've only had the opportunity to visit Gokyuzu once while on vacation in London, but the lamb shish was delicious. I had tried another Turkish restaurant down the street a couple times, and I think the lamb shish take-away is better here. The restaurant is basically located in a Turkish/Eastern European neighborhood of London, so there's a lot of competition nearby. That said, I think this place is worth the wait and I will definitely keep it in mind for my next visit to London. Already looking forward to trying some other items off their menu.

rpcX5sMlQa7pzk8rESxZiA.text: The best lamb shish I have ever had. Free salad - they've done something to it that made me ask them to pack it up for me so I can finish it at home! Delicious.Cold aubergine meze starter (sadly...forgot the name!) - light, refreshing, perfect compliment to the lamb.Free tea - bonus!Warm squidgy bread on arrival with cold refreshing tzatziki - I am not a bread person, but goodness it was so warm and soft and heavenly - I couldn't resist to have a couple of slices.I went there for a Sunday lunch with myself - it was packed!Service? Great.I'm going back to try out the rest of their menu!

J5fFGO8p0jfJXkS9XYeG0w.text: At this authentic Turkish eatery, your meal starts with complimentary Turkish bread, dips & salad, but make sure to leave space for the wide range of delicious starters!Dishes include mezze such as hummous, haloumi & Turkish pizza breads. Mixed platters of mezze or mains are available which are huge mountains of chargrilled meat, rice and salads. We ordered so much that we had to take half of it home with us! If you still have any space you can finish with baklava and Turkish tea! The price was very reasonable and service friendly. The only downside was it was very busy on a Saturday night & we had to wait quite a while for a table, but a takeaway option is available for those lucky enough to live nearby!

gg7CJgsQcSlyEch8b4CDPg.text: Everything was great: place, service and food.   They make their own bread in wood oven. Try the Ezmeli Kuzu Sis; one of the most tender and tasty lamb I have tried.

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom

7c80LnCxGgecSdVazJW0nA.text: It gets incredibly busy on a Saturday  we had to wait 15 mins for a table even though we booked  but was really delicious.We had a more starters than we needed and some delicious starters. That plus a fair few drinks (& tip) was £19 each. Definitely recommendation from me.

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom

OdpuJFGswie7Gmk1fy6AWA.text: The best Turkish restaurant in London! The food is mouth watering. Don't let the long queue put you down, it is sooooo worth waiting. If you are in a big group of meat eaters only, I suggest ordering the platter that way you can have a bit of almost everything. Variety of veggie options available too. Can't fault the staff, always very pleasant and very helpful.

XVfYOnAbkrki41lkIWoEvQ.text: They serve sex on a plate. Seriously, amazingly good Turkish food, so much so that Gokyuzu has now joined my love triangle with Durum in Finchley Central and Kilim in Muswell Hill.I had my favorite lamb shish, wrapped with salad and chilli sauce. We also got some patlican soslu which is aubergine and green peppers in a tomatoey sauce, some bulgur wheat and lahmacun which is a kind of Turkish pizza.It was absolutely buzzing on Saturday night and it's certainly had a refurb in recent times. Half of the space is a restaurant and the other half is for takeaway, both sides were busy and there seemed to be a lot of Turkish people in there - always a good sign of authentic cuisine!The wrap was all kinds of delicious and what made is stand out for me was the chunks of cucumber here and there which were so cooling against the chilli sauce and gave the wrap a good bite.All of the dishes were as tasty as they looked and smelt, no wonder this place is so busy - really great Turkish cuisine, I'll definitely be back to try some more dishes (just don't tell Durum or Kilim!!)

oI3xxaYi-ShRPGEY2E1-xA.text: Busy local restaurant. Delicious meze and succulent meats in a friendly and efficiently run place. Portions are enormous so bring an appetite. Easy on the wallet as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom. Working up an appetite while waiting for a table

ETM3-tDwKxfRSErHWjqSUA.text: BEST RESTAURANT IN LONDON!!!I love this place. Try the rice pudding --Lamb chunks!!!!!!!Its cheap, too!!!

wiooQnCyW8We1CKT3elG-Q.text: First time here tonight succulent lamb doner kebab with fresh salad and Greek yogurt, large of course with drinks it's £8 each decent atmosphere

Pk9qkKbfTzEGKBJIMBSArA.text: This Turkish restaurant is located on the main street (Green Lanes), parking can be an issue, especially with the super efficient traffic wardens and the CCTV cameras! The restaurant does not look like much from the outside, but boy the food is simply delicious, it makes one of the best lahmacun i ever tried. For main we ordered a mix grill, when it arrived it was just so enticing, it consisted of meat & chicken cubes, kofte, chicken wings, etc. The quantity was enough for 3, it comes with salad & home made bread with a yogurt & cucumber sauce. Its was lovely, succulent and tasty.The service is great, really had a nice evening meal with the family. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.Their website is gokyuzurestaurant.co.uk

iULEaYDeCiN_DtWvUtQNuA.text: Gokyuzu has undergone a makeover in recent months, taking over the neighbouring premises and modernising their decor and installing plain wooden furniture. Although popular for Saturday lunch, we were soon seated and orders were taken and completed quickly. Starting with a meze comprising four dishes including houmous, aubergine, and a creamy mix called haydari, only the prawn dish was a little under par. The children had chicken shish served with rice and salad which was eaten with gusto, a good sign, and hubby had a chicken dish which resembled a wrap chopped into slices which he said was good. My lamb shish was nice but could have been a little more tender perhaps. Too full to attempt desserts, but we did order some salty, frothy ayrans which went down quickly. Meal for 4 (no alcohol) was £30 and we hardly needed to eat for the rest of the day. Very family friendly, highchairs available

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom

IUC6_c_Ua6W3Z5Nr61QNVw.text: I love this little restaurant. I often go to North London to stock up on Turkish food from green lanes. I discovered this tiny restaurant a couple of years ago. It's a real gem. I've eaten in many Turkish restaurants, both here and in Istanbul, and this place is one of my favourites. when I first saw it I thought it was one of those cheap, awful food places, hunger drove me in and it was fantastic. It's never empty and sometimes you have to Que to get a table. The food is super and what I like about it the most is they offer you a free selection of Mezes and flat bread before you even order. Every time I'm in London I eat here. Even if I have to go out of my way and sit in that traffic.

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom

VRbF9nt5EUD7srwzUFZMKg.text: Went there by chance yesterday for a family dinner. It was surprisingly busy for a Wednesday night, which made us choose to go in in a first place.We were seated straight away, the staff were friendly and the food was veeeery delicious. Got the set meal for 2, so we can try all of their meat and were impressed by the quality. All in extremely large portions, I had to take quite a lot home with me, as it seemed like a big waste to leave:) In the end we got some baklava on the house!Definitely recommended!!!:)

N_W5cCPWMBtFrq00QJtiiA.text: Favorite place in London! Incredible food , amazing service and so affordable!

fU9e6pyt0dHSxrCdXUe3QA.text: Love the Lamb and chicken group platter ! The tea was great too. We didn't have to wait to be seated ( we had a reservation). The restaurant was clean and chic! I Loved it and will come back again for sure!

sfkj2hXWcXFIlUx104BPBQ.text: Yum yum yum.This place was all around good and all around packed.  Some good items and some not so good, details to follow, but generally I would go back and would recommend friends here too!Four of us went and this was almost too much food.Starters:Hummus - yummy and with substance.  I sometime find that hummus can be too pureed, but that was not the problem here! Would order again.Babaganush - This was one that was okay... it was a little creamy for me, I and my dining partners prefer more aubergine heavy BBG.  Would skip next time.Hellim - this grilled halloumi was to die for.  It came out hot and melty (in as much as halloumi could be melty). Would definitely order again.Muska Boregi - this was an off the cuff order, but was delicious! Would definitely order again.Mains:Chicken Wings - flavourful and moist.  Some people wanted sauce (which we got - spicy and mint), but I thought these were delicious without.  Would order again.Adana Kebab - this is my all time favourite turkish dish.  I can't say its the best minced lamb kebab I've ever had, but it was good. Spiced well and moist.  Would order again.Sea Bass - this was definitely the star of the night. It was moist and pulled right off the bone (heads up as it comes as a whole fish!).  The spice/chutney on top were amazing and complemented, but did not over power the fish itself.  A few complaints about bones, but really they were pretty easy to avoid/spot as you chew and is a side effect of whole fish plates! I would definitely order this again!

dvY6x6cvnimvAG4QNJPHUw.text: This place is so fresh-it feels really nice to eat here after being in search of FRESH & lite fare! The salad they provide is delicious and they also give you their yogurt and cucumber dip along with delicious home baked flat bread..ALL DELICIOUS already. Next the appetizers, the Baba ghanough was one of my favorite starters-it was so perfectly made and balanced, different and better than what I'm used to. The fried halloumi is fried cheese...def a win-I love halloumi cheese! The feta and melon was good; the feta is a mild feta cheese (which I actually liked).  We were already pretty full here, but then our orders came. We ordered the iskandar kabob, Adana kabob, and chicken doner...everyone was happy and ate almost all of their food (and there is a lot of food) We couldn't resist ordering dessert, considering how delicious the food was...it was a must! And WOW.....it's a must. The kunafa-#1 top kunafa I've ever had...served with cream/butter that is exceptionally tasty with the kunafa! The rice pudding-#2 favorite and delicious! Not too sweet, slight hint of rosewAter...tasty!The cheesecake-#3-fresh pomegranate on top of delicious not too sweet cheese. This was my sisters favorite.  She claimed it was one of the most unique and delicious cheesecakes she has ever had!The baklava:#4 the pistachios in the baklava were so delicious, but this wasn't our favorite balaclava ever! I would fly to London to eat here!

2JK18DVBoe3m3HND7NNt5A.text: Not sure where to start but I'd take a flight out just to go eat. This place is heaven on earth. Very busy but understandable after you dine there. They are generous with their portions and that's a good and bad thing...it's so good you don't want to stop. The salad they give you for starters makes my mouth water just thinking about it and the bread well let's just say I can go on carb overload and be totally ok with it!  The veggie appetizers are all amazing and the icing on the cake...drum roll please- wow the kunefe and my favorite that I say dream about, the cheesecake with pomegranate. I love love this place. I'll be back. And yes, I dined there a few times on my trip to London.

1VAZOlZwrHJ8QCA9wo75hQ.text: Good standard Turkish restaurant.  The pide and Adana kebab were both very tasty and the service friendly and attentive. The spinach and garlic yogurt dip was a disappointment. Very little garlic taste and not enough spinach.

Ymn3RqhRupI2sJEZx5RDDA.text: Gokyuzu was highly recommended to us by a relative, and so we ventured FAR up the Piccadilly line for lunch today. Here are my thoughts:Ambiance is great. This place is casual but clean with an airy feel.Service is just okay...our server was a bit impatient but this could have been a language barrier on both sides?Food was good and not-so-good.-- Salad was delicious. Loved everything about it. -- Lamb kabob was excellent according to my 10-year-old who devoured it.-- Vegetable stew wasn't really a stew at all but just dried mixed vegetables accompanied by rice. I didn't enjoy this much.-- Chicken kabob was undercooked - my husband had to send it back for additional cooking. Overall Gokyuzu was just okay for us. Since we're in the minority it could be that we just didn't order right? So if we're in the area we might give it another go.

XDN1v2M3zXin7Y4XvFR-2w.text: Hope you are hungry .. Refreshing to know that a visit to this fine Turkish establishment will guarantee you walk out the door fully satiated. Servings are generous, restaurant is spacious (so you can just turn up), and prices economical. Make sure you visit with a friend so that you can share dishes .. On my visit delicious fresh bread and tea were thrown in complimentary.

WnOYtttbNDg2tSNEUo307g.text: How could I not have reviewed this place yet?! Everything about this place is amazing - the food is plentiful and delicious. Especially the meat which is tasty and cooked to perfection. The platters are huge! We took food home for the next day because we couldn't finish it all. The service was great, the manager is very friendly despite how busy the restaurant is. And be warned: this place is constantly full - call ahead for a reservation.Highly, highly recommend.

-NIsP0ofPNpRhS7V9gme0A.text: Had an excellent meal here on a Saturday afternoon.They bring you - automatically, i.e. without your asking - a basket of fresh bread (something akin to pita) with a yoghurt-cucumber type dip, followed by a salad with toppings like beetroot and carrot, tomato. The missus and I were broadly down with this, figuring this was just customary for the restaurant; and we assumed that we would be charged for it at the end of the meal. We were incorrect. These two starters, both of which were great and far beyond anything I have ever had in the 'free starter' department.The mains (lamb grill for me, chicken soup for her) were both good, tasty and hearty. Generous portions, very good value.The service was attentive and matter-of-fact. I don't need servers to be my buddy - I prefer it when they are effective, and these folks definitely were. Attentive without being overbearing, and friendly enough so that I never felt like I was an imposition. It's hard to strike this balance, and the servers here did it well.The restaurant itself is reasonably large but it doesn't feel cavernous or anything, and the servers manage the space efficiently. On our visit, it was busy but we were seated quickly nonetheless. It's not a fancy setup, but it's all clean and light and quite comfortable. The clientele ranged broadly in terms of demographics, from teenagers to pensioners, families with their children, couples, groups of friends, many different races and ethnicities. Great to see so many people getting down with Turkish food.This place was excellent from top to bottom. Great food, excellent service and unbelievable value. I would highly recommend a visit.

wD1tjek42k4PL5nhd8RDvg.text: Probably one of the best meals that I had in London to date. It's location is not the easiest, but it is well worth the trip. We walked in on a packed Saturday evening; however, we were seated relative quickly (note we were only two, I'd assume a longer wait for more people). As soon as we sat down, we were given delicious warm pide and cacik sauce. We also received a large salad before even ordering a meal. All of the appetisers and entrees had unbelievable flavour as well. Overall, the service was friendly and fast, and the atmosphere was enjoyable. Highly recommend, especially if you want to have a night away from a pub.

photos.caption: Photo of Gokyuzu - London, United Kingdom

1M0VMIuZFqmKo0Gh9UAxyw.text: I think I've had better food here than in Istanbul. Seriously.The place was jammed to the gills when we arrived around 7:30 Saturday night. And it only got more crowded the later it got. But hot damn, I understand why! The service is INCREDIBLY efficient once seated and the platters of food are HUGE. The aubergine dip is liked smoked, creamy, delicious crack. I could have inhaled the whole round plate, with dollops of olive oil and warm pita bread, but had to restrain myself. I also hot the halloumi pide with a sprinkling of red peppers (they were a bit stingy there, as more red peppers would have been good). Melted halloumi+ warm bread= winning.My husband got a lamb dish which was similarly enormous and he said quite flavorful.I got the house Turkish wine and it was bland, bland, but no fault of the restaurant. For two people, an app, two main dishes, a wine and diet coke (with leftovers to boot) for 51 quid was a steal. We would happily return and bring others!

QLt7_PmmstyyIRZheK3WLg.text: What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said. Have to give it 5* for everything. Only slight niggle is that the place does get absolutely rammed at weekends and they pack the table close together which can be a little clostraphobic.

p05Ld-eHFJ2iZlF_HpPszg.text: Lucky us to get Turkish food in a big Turkish neighborhood in London.  This place is bustling and exciting, with waiters running around and calling out to each other.  Though they have a menu of many Turkish standards, we were told by friends that our group of 6 would be getting the Large Mixed Meze and Jumbo Platter for £52 total - which was an absolute bargain for a big group!  I'd have liked a bit more meze, as they were all delicious (lots of dips, like spinach/yogurt, hummus, dill/feta/yogurt, as well as aubergine in tomato sauce and a bulgar salad - but despite the platter serving 4-5 people, the 6 of us we were all taking teeny tiny portions from it.  Admittedly, we wanted to save room for the meat.  But I'd say this is appropriate for 3-4 hungry people really.  But it was all delicious and at my friend's request, they brought us both regular bread and bread that's apparently brushed with lamb juice or something like that?  That was special, but all the bread was lovely.  I love Turkish bread!  I should say in addition to the mezze they brought us some unexpected freebies like a beetroot and carrot salad and another dip, and I think they gave us something else free the end (maybe Turkish delight?  Sounds familiar).The Jumbo Platter is served with rice and bulgur, and is a huge pile of all kinds of meat: Lamb Shish, Chicken Shish, Adana Kebab, Lamb Ribs, Chicken Doner, Lamb Doner, Chicken Wings, Lamb Chops.  If it sounds exceptional, it was, both in concept and execution.  It is hard to describe the meat feast that took place that evening - we all stuffed ourselves silly and I think we may even have left a bit behind!  The lamb ribs were outstanding, and I don't think I'd ever had them before!  Lamb chops were also delicious, but all the more standard meats were great too - juicy and flavorful.  This is such a fantastic place to get great Turkish food for not much money, big portions, and it's a blast to share it with your friends.  Loved the busy atmosphere, was a great way to kick off our Saturday night!

w7q-WznuzIOKx-l1Aup1TQ.text: After seeing all the raving reviews for Gokyuzu we trekked all the way to Haringey to try.  On a Sunday evening the place was busy but we managed to get a table immediately.  Portions were generous but I did not find the food anything special.  The Turkish pizza/lahmacun was particularly disappointing, the dough was thick and soggy.  I can find much better crispy freshly baked lahmacun in Islington at Antepliler without going all the way to Haringey.  Or there are numerous Turkish restaurants in Hackney.  Gokyuzu was not worth the effort to go to for a greasy meal of cheap grilled meat.

TAuzAWuS1B1Ij2LxIyVfLg.text: Excellent food!!! We came after hearing so many good things and the restaurant definitely lived up to its expectations! The food was ah-mazing! Service was prompt and efficient. As soon as we sat down, we were served with bread, salad and yogurt. It literally didn't take more than a minute and boom--we were already grubbing. We ordered the jumbo platter and although there were 4 of us, there was plenty left over. We'll definitely be back soon.

1bjRzE7N-x-7Q6DmSvEqqA.text: I remember when it was opened and its first days. They were really busy and nothing has changed since then. It tells everything. I always order lamb beyti which is great and they are the best indeed. I don't want to repeat other reviews but can't finish my review without stating that:Mix grill is huge can be shared with 4-5 pplSalads are mouthwateringBread is warm and delicious (You can be full even with bread and salad)Don't forget to get your free Turkish tea

hF4jPfamt384U0vmyro-jg.text: Another first rate Turkish restaurant in London.And this is a good one.Fantastic raw ingredients don't hurt here.Superlative yogurt - almost like whipped cream.Great flat bread.The salads are very subtly dressed - and thus depend on great raw ingredients -and they absolutely deliver on that front.One cheese and vegetable salad we ordered stood about eight inches off the plate - a one person serving that would have fed a whole potluck.The slivered cheese came in a thick layer of about two to three inches on the top - and was first rate stuff. Underneath that in the greens, the slivered cabbage and the cucumbers were 20 to 25 fantastic olives - more than one gets in a dish of olives in some spanish restaurants.Lamb soup was simple hardy stuff - fine as it was straight from the kitchen - and even better when doctored with the generous array of condiments provided on the table. (A great Turkish hot sauce and a nice strong sumac powder were available and welcome.) Note - lamb soup without a drop of grease - a sign of attention in the cooking.Vegetable stew had strong tastes on each of the ingredients and every vegetable had its own flavor.(How many ratatouille variants have you had of eggplant/marrow/tomato/basil mush all cooked together to the point of being practically bolognese sauce?)Mint tea with about triple the mint leaves you get in some other places.And even though the lines to get in are humongous - the service never rushes anyone - and attentively offers you all sorts of goodies like a good host.This place is highly popular and that popularity is well deserved.

VmfQEGVstqQEc-TkKLxNVA.text: First Turkish restaurant on the Turkish district and completely blown away by the food. Kebab dish that we ordered was pretty good, so were the mezes (arnavut cigeri bir harika!) but Lahmacun was the highlight of the dinner. It has the perfect blend of spices and crust, absolutely delicious. Highly recommended!

aWhpUvcUyBU-48N6_kwlOw.text: It's good. I guess. Not for me though. Most men love it, as the meet is a hill on your plate, but all the meet tasted like the thing you light the charcoal with.... all the same white spirits taste.Still very good are the daily stews. This I recommend. If you come: there might be a long queue on the weekend and some evenings! But try yourself.Or stick to their veg and stew.Or go to Antepiler next door for a truly awesome and cheap fresh crunchy tasty Lahmacun :)

GSyJFBQwPd08Q8sw6yH3YA.text: This is my top 5 place in London. If you read other reviews you'll already know why but here's a few pointers.- Turkish food gives HUGE portions. - Get the platter if in a group. The meat platter gives you every charcoal meat you can think of (doner, shish, ribs, wings, small pieces) along with a few peppers and some amazing rice. I honestly would take the hard work of looking through single dishes on menu and just get this. - The free salads and bread that come with the platter are exceptional. Turkish salad is great on it's own to be honest. - The starter mezes are lovely.- The free tea. Ah unlimited free tea. Just ask. - The service. They like most Turks are renowned for customer service.- Sometimes you even get free Baklava.- It's a buzzing place and is always packed. But this adds to the experience.- You can take away your food in a doggy bag. Meaning GET THE PLATTER. Then save some for the next day. It's just too good!Gokyuzu for me is THE place to go to on Green Lanes. The hub of a Turkish community where you will find many great restaurants in fact (Hala, Antepliler, Diyabakir). But Gokyuzu is the most popular for good reason. Come hungry and if you like tasty meat and the meat sweats that will come with it. Come here.
